presentations.title: Virtualization Technology Research
presentations.description: A comprehensive technical presentation covering virtualization fundamentals, hypervisors, platforms, and modern extensions.

sections.title: Virtualization Technology
sections.subtitle: Essential Research (16-Slide Overview)
sections.content: A condensed technical exploration of virtualization fundamentals, hypervisor architectures, platform comparisons, and modern extensions.

sections.title: Virtualization Fundamentals
sections.content:
Virtualization abstracts physical hardware to run multiple isolated environments on one machine.

• **Core Goal**: Maximize utilization (from 10% to 80%+) and reduce server sprawl.
• **Architecture**: A Hypervisor (VMM) translates and allocates physical resources.
• **Benefits**: Rapid provisioning, lower TCO, and simplified disaster recovery.

sections.title: CPU Virtualization
sections.content:
Hardware-assisted CPU virtualization enables near-native performance for virtual workloads.

• **Protection Rings**: x86 uses rings 0-3. Hypervisors use Ring -1 (Root Mode) to manage Guest OS in Ring 0.
• **Hardware Support**: Intel VT-x and AMD-V provide the necessary VMX instruction sets.
• **VM Exits**: Minimizes expensive transitions between Guest and Host modes.

sections.title: Memory Virtualization
sections.content:
Efficient address translation is the backbone of virtualized memory management.

• **Address Layers**: Translates Guest Virtual Address (GVA) to Guest Physical (GPA) to Host Physical (HPA).
• **Hardware Tables**: Extended/Nested Page Tables (EPT/NPT) handle this translation in hardware silicon.
• **Performance**: Significantly reduces memory access latency and hypervisor overhead.

sections.title: I/O Virtualization Techniques
sections.content:
Efficient I/O is critical for networking and storage performance.

• **Emulation**: Full simulation; maximum compatibility but highest overhead.
• **Paravirtualization (Virtio)**: Guest-aware drivers with shared memory queues; balanced performance.
• **SR-IOV**: Direct hardware function access; bypasses hypervisor for true bare-metal speeds.

sections.title: Type 1 vs Type 2 Hypervisors
sections.content:
The choice of architecture defines the performance and use-case boundaries.

• **Type 1 (Bare-Metal)**: Installs directly on hardware. Best for production, enterprise, and cloud. (ESXi, KVM, Hyper-V).
• **Type 2 (Hosted)**: Runs as an app on a host OS. Best for development, testing, and classrooms. (VirtualBox, Workstation).

items.title: VM Lifecycle

items.title: CPU Scheduling
items.description: Mapping vCPUs to pCPUs via fair-share algorithms, reservations, and affinity pinning.

items.title: Resource Isolation

items.title: Management Layer

items.title: Data

sections.title: 1. The Partitioned Family (Hyper-V)
sections.content:
Microsoft uses a Partitioned architecture where the Root (Parent) partition manages the hardware.

• **Root Partition**: The main Windows OS; owns the physical drivers.
• **Child Partitions**: The VMs. Use Virtualization Service Clients (VSC).
• **The VMBus**: High-speed communication tunnel for child-to-parent I/O.
• **Products**: Windows Server (Hyper-V), Azure Stack HCI, Windows Pro.

sections.title: 2. The Monolithic Family (VMware)
sections.content:
VMware ESXi is a self-contained 'mini-OS' designed specifically for virtualization.

• **VMkernel**: A specialized, monolithic kernel that includes its own drivers and management stack.
• **Independence**: No 'main OS' (like Windows) runs on top. The hypervisor is the only thing on the hardware.
• **Products**: vSphere (Enterprise), Workstation (Desktop), and Fusion (Mac).

sections.title: 3. The Microkernel Family (Xen)
sections.content:
Xen uses a tiny core hypervisor that offloads hardware management to a privileged VM.

• **Dom0 (Domain 0)**: A highly-privileged VM that manages hardware drivers and other domains.
• **DomU (User Domains)**: Standard, unprivileged virtual machines.
• **Security**: Extreme isolation; this design was the original foundation for AWS EC2.

sections.title: 4. The Kernel-Based Family (KVM)
sections.content:
KVM turns the Linux kernel itself into a Type 1 hypervisor via a simple kernel module.

• **VMs as Processes**: Each VM is literally a standard Linux process (manageable via `kill` or `top`).
• **Native Efficiency**: Levages existing Linux features for memory and task scheduling.
• **Products**: Proxmox, Nutanix AHV, and the engine for AWS Nitro & Google Cloud.

sections.title: 5. The OS-Level Family (LXC)
sections.content:
Linux Containers (LXC) provide isolated sandboxes without the need for hardware virtualization.

• **The 'Cheat'**: Shares the host's kernel and uses Namespaces (isolation) and Cgroups (limits).
• **Performance**: Near-zero overhead and millisecond startup times.
• **The Limit**: Host and Guest must share the same kernel (Linux-only). Products: LXD, Incus, Proxmox.

sections.title: Linux & OS Architecture Deep Dive
sections.subtitle: From Kernel to User Space
sections.content: A condensed technical exploration of operating system fundamentals, Linux internals, distribution comparisons, and advanced administration.

items.title: What is an OS?
items.description: The resource allocator and control program. Manages Processes, Memory, Storage, and Security.

items.title: The Kernel (The Core)
items.description: Monolithic (Linux): All drivers & FS in one space (Fast). Microkernel: Minimal core, services in user space (Stable).

items.title: Protection Rings
items.description: Ring 0: Kernel Mode (Full Access). Ring 3: User Mode (Restricted).

sections.title: What is Linux?
sections.content: Linux is a free, open-source Unix-like operating system kernel created by Linus Torvalds in 1991. Combined with GNU tools, it forms a complete operating system powering everything from smartphones to supercomputers.

items.title: The Formula
items.description: Linux Kernel + GNU Tools + Package Manager + Desktop/Server Config = Distribution (Distro)

items.title: Why Multiple Distros?
items.description: Different philosophies: Stability vs Cutting-edge, Simplicity vs Control, Enterprise vs Community.

items.title: Core Components
items.description: All distros share the Linux kernel but differ in package management, init systems, and default software.

items.title: Debian Family
items.description: Ubuntu, Debian, Linux Mint. Best for: Desktops, cloud, beginners. Package: .deb (APT).

items.title: RHEL Family
items.description: CentOS, Rocky, Fedora, AlmaLinux. Best for: Servers, enterprises, ISPs. Package: .rpm (DNF/YUM).

items.title: Arch Family
items.description: Arch, Manjaro. Best for: Advanced users, customization. Package: pacman. Rolling release.

items.title: SUSE Family
items.description: openSUSE, SLES. Best for: European enterprises, YaST configuration tool.

items.title: Specialized
items.description: Alpine (containers), Kali (security), Raspberry Pi OS (embedded).

items.title: BIOS/UEFI
items.description: Hardware check (POST).

items.title: GRUB2
items.description: Loads Kernel & Initrd.

items.title: Kernel
items.description: Mounts root FS, starts init.

items.title: Systemd
items.description: Parallel service startup.

items.title: Inter-Process Communication (IPC)
items.description: How apps talk: Pipes, Sockets, Signals, Shared Memory.

items.title: /bin
items.description: Essential binary or executable programs required for basic system operation.

items.title: /etc
items.description: System-wide configuration files used to control system behavior (e.g., fstab, passwd).

items.title: /home
items.description: User home directories and default working directory for users.

items.title: /opt
items.description: Optional or third-party software packages installed separately from the system.

items.title: /tmp
items.description: Temporary storage space for files, typically cleared on system reboot.

items.title: /usr
items.description: User-related programs, utilities, and shared resources.

items.title: /var
items.description: Variable data such as log files that change frequently during system operation.

items.title: /proc & /dev
items.description: Virtual filesystems: /proc (kernel runtime info), /dev (hardware devices like sda).

items.title: Release Cycle

presentations.title: DHCP - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
presentations.description: A comprehensive technical presentation covering DHCP fundamentals, DORA process, Linux implementation, and ISP deployment strategies.

sections.title: DHCP
sections.subtitle: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
sections.content: Automatic IP address assignment and network configuration for modern networks.

sections.title: What is DHCP?
sections.content: DHCP is an application layer protocol that automatically assigns IP addresses and network configuration to devices. It operates on UDP ports 67 (server) and 68 (client), eliminating manual IP configuration and preventing address conflicts.

items.title: DHCP Server
items.description: Stores IP addresses and configuration details. Allocates addresses dynamically to clients.

items.title: DHCP Client
items.description: A device (PC, phone, printer, etc.) that requests and receives network configuration from the server.

items.title: DHCP Relay
items.description: Acts as a bridge between clients and servers when they are not on the same subnet.

items.title: IP Address Pool
items.description: A predefined range of IP addresses that the DHCP server can lease to devices.

items.title: Lease
items.description: The time period for which an IP address is assigned to a client. After expiry, the client must renew or request a new lease.

items.title: Options
items.description: Additional parameters like subnet mask, default gateway, DNS servers, domain name, and time servers.

items.title: D - Discover
items.description: Client broadcasts to find DHCP servers on the network.

items.title: O - Offer
items.description: Server responds with an available IP address and configuration.

items.title: R - Request
items.description: Client accepts the offer and requests the IP address.

items.title: A - Acknowledge
items.description: Server confirms the lease and binds the IP to the client.

sections.title: 1. DHCP Discover
sections.content:
**Client Broadcasts:**

- Source IP: 0.0.0.0 (client has no IP yet)
- Destination IP: 255.255.255.255 (broadcast)
- Source MAC: Client's MAC address
- Destination MAC: FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF (broadcast)

**Purpose:** Client searches for available DHCP servers on the network.

**Packet Size:** 342 or 576 bytes

sections.title: 2. DHCP Offer
sections.content:
**Server Responds:**

- Source IP: Server's IP address
- Destination IP: 255.255.255.255 (broadcast) or client IP
- Offered IP: Available IP from the pool
- Lease Time: Duration of the IP assignment (e.g., 72 hours)

**Purpose:** Server proposes an IP address and network configuration to the client.

**Note:** If multiple servers exist, client accepts the first offer received.

sections.title: 3. DHCP Request
sections.content:
**Client Accepts:**

- Source IP: 0.0.0.0 (still no IP)
- Destination IP: 255.255.255.255 (broadcast)
- Requested IP: The offered IP address
- Server Identifier: ID of the chosen server

**Purpose:** Client broadcasts acceptance of the offer and requests the IP address.

**ARP Check:** Client sends gratuitous ARP to detect IP conflicts before accepting.

sections.title: 4. DHCP Acknowledgment
sections.content:
**Server Confirms:**

- Source IP: Server's IP address
- Destination IP: Client's new IP or broadcast
- Lease Binding: Server creates entry with client ID and lease time

**Purpose:** Server confirms the lease and the client can now use the IP address.

**Result:** IP address is bound to the client and will not be assigned to others during the lease period.

items.title: DHCP NACK (Negative Acknowledgment)
items.description: Server rejects the request when the IP is invalid or the pool is exhausted.

items.title: DHCP Decline
items.description: Client rejects the offered IP (e.g., if ARP detects a conflict).

items.title: DHCP Release
items.description: Client voluntarily releases the IP address back to the server.

items.title: DHCP Inform
items.description: Client requests additional configuration parameters (already has an IP).

items.title: ISC DHCP Server
items.description: Industry-standard DHCP server: dhcpd. Install: apt install isc-dhcp-server (Ubuntu) or dnf install dhcp-server (CentOS).

items.title: Configuration File
items.description: /etc/dhcp/dhcpd.conf - Define subnets, IP ranges, lease times, DNS servers, and gateways.

items.title: Service Management
items.description: systemctl start dhcpd, systemctl enable dhcpd, systemctl status dhcpd.

items.title: Lease Database
items.description: /var/lib/dhcpd/dhcpd.leases - Tracks active leases and client bindings.
journalctl -u dhcpd -f or /var/log/syslog for troubleshooting.

items.title: DHCP Failover (High Availability)
items.description: Configure Primary/Secondary peers on VMs to sync leases via TCP 647. Ensures service continuity if one node fails.

items.title: DHCP Starvation Attack
items.description: Attackers flood DHCP requests to exhaust the IP pool. Mitigation: DHCP snooping, rate limiting.

items.title: Rogue DHCP Servers
items.description: Fake servers assign malicious configurations. Mitigation: DHCP snooping, port security on switches.

items.title: Man-in-the-Middle Attacks
items.description: Attackers intercept traffic via fake servers. Mitigation: Network segmentation, monitoring.

items.title: DNS Hijacking
items.description: Malicious DNS servers redirect traffic. Mitigation: Validate DHCP server authenticity, use DNSSEC.

items.title: Customer IP Assignment
items.description: DHCP assigns dynamic IPs to residential customers. Reduces IP waste and simplifies management.

items.title: Lease Management
items.description: Short leases (24-72 hours) for residential. Long leases or static IPs for business customers.

items.title: Failover & Redundancy
items.description: Two DHCP servers in failover mode prevent service disruption. Critical for 24/7 ISP operations.

items.title: DHCP Relay Agents
items.description: Relay DHCP requests across VLANs and subnets. Essential for multi-site ISP networks.

items.title: Integration with RADIUS
items.description: DHCP works with RADIUS for authentication and accounting in ISP billing systems.

items.title: Why CentOS/Rocky?
items.description: ISC DHCP on CentOS/Rocky provides 10-year support, proven stability, and telecom-grade reliability.

presentations.title: DNS - Domain Name System
presentations.description: A comprehensive technical presentation covering DNS fundamentals, the resolution process, software landscape, and deep dives into BIND and MaraDNS.

sections.title: DNS
sections.subtitle: Domain Name System
sections.content: The internet's phonebook: translating human-readable names into IP addresses.

sections.title: What is DNS?
sections.content: DNS (Domain Name System) is a hierarchical and decentralized naming system for computers, services, or other resources connected to the Internet or a private network. It primarily operates on UDP and TCP port 53, resolving names like `google.com` to IP addresses like `142.250.190.46`.

items.title: Root Servers (.)
items.description: The top of the hierarchy. There are 13 logical root server addresses globally. They know where the TLD servers are.

items.title: TLD Servers (.com, .org, .net)
items.description: Top-Level Domain servers know which authoritative servers manage specific domains (like google.com).

items.title: Authoritative Name Servers
items.description: These hold the actual DNS records (A, MX, TXT) for a specific domain. The final answer.

items.title: Recursive Resolvers
items.description: Servers (like 8.8.8.8, 1.1.1.1, or your ISP's DNS) that perform the full lookup process on behalf of the client.

sections.title: The DNS Resolution Process
sections.content:
1. **Query:** Browser asks Recursive Resolver for 'example.com'.
2. **Root lookup:** Resolver queries Root Server (.).
3. **TLD redirect:** Root returns TLD Server (.com) IP.
4. **TLD lookup:** Resolver queries TLD Server.
5. **Auth redirect:** TLD returns Authoritative Server IP.
6. **Auth lookup:** Resolver queries Authoritative Server.
7. **Resolution:** Auth Server returns IP for 'example.com'.
8. **Response:** Resolver gives IP to Browser.

items.title: A Record
items.description: Address record. Maps a domain name to an IPv4 address.

items.title: AAAA Record
items.description: IPv6 Address record. Maps a domain name to an IPv6 address.

items.title: CNAME
items.description: Canonical Name. Maps an alias name to a true (canonical) domain name. (e.g., www pointing to the root domain).

items.title: MX Record
items.description: Mail Exchange. Specifies the mail servers responsible for accepting email messages on behalf of a domain.

items.title: TXT Record
items.description: Text record. Used for holding arbitrary text, highly utilized for email security (SPF, DKIM, DMARC).

items.title: NS Record
items.description: Name Server record. Indicates which DNS servers are authoritative for a domain.

items.title: BIND (Berkeley Internet Name Domain)
items.description: The de facto standard. Oldest, most feature-rich, handles both Authoritative and Recursive roles.

items.title: PowerDNS
items.description: High performance, database-backed (MySQL/PostgreSQL) authoritative server. Great for ISPs and large deployments.

items.title: Unbound
items.description: A very secure, validating, recursive, and caching DNS resolver. Focused strictly on recursive duties.

items.title: CoreDNS
items.description: Modern, flexible, written in Go. Widely used in Kubernetes and cloud-native environments.

items.title: MaraDNS
items.description: Tiny, lightweight, highly secure, focused on small footprint and embedded systems.

sections.title: BIND DNS - The Industry Standard
sections.content: BIND 9, maintained by the Internet Systems Consortium (ISC), is the most widely deployed DNS server on the Internet. It is a full-featured software suite capable of acting as both an Authoritative Name Server and a Recursive Resolver.

items.title: Configuration Model
items.description: Configured primarily via `/etc/named.conf`. Zone data is stored in plain text zone files.

items.title: Dual Role Capability
items.description: Can serve public zones (authoritative) while simultaneously resolving queries for internal clients (recursive). Often separated in modern security models.

items.title: Advanced Features
items.description: Supports DNSSEC (signing and validation), TSIG (secure zone transfers), Views (split-horizon DNS), and Dynamic DNS (DDNS).

items.title: Enterprise Use Cases
items.description: Root servers, TLD infrastructure, enterprise internal DNS, and traditional ISP resolving servers.

items.title: Drawbacks
items.description: Complex configuration syntax, historically prone to vulnerabilities (though much improved in BIND 9), heavier resource footprint.

sections.title: MaraDNS - The Lightweight Alternative
sections.content: MaraDNS is a small, secure, and easy-to-configure DNS server. Designed with an intense focus on security and a minimal resource footprint, it splits functionality between MaraDNS (authoritative) and Deadwood (recursive).

items.title: Security-First Design
items.description: Written from scratch to avoid buffer overflows. Has a history of very few security vulnerabilities compared to BIND.

items.title: Split Architecture
items.description: Authoritative serving is handled by MaraDNS. Recursive caching is handled by a separate, tiny program called Deadwood.

items.title: Configuration Model
items.description: Uses a very simple configuration file (`mararc`). Zone files use a highly simplified custom syntax.

items.title: Use Cases
items.description: Embedded routers, small IoT devices, lightweight local development environments, and secure, simple authoritative servers.

items.title: Drawbacks
items.description: Lacks complex features like robust DNSSEC signing, views, or database backends. Not designed for massive enterprise load.

items.title: Complexity
items.description: BIND: Very High | MaraDNS: Very Low

items.title: Feature Set
items.description: BIND: Everything (DNSSEC, Views, DDNS) | MaraDNS: Basic resolution and serving only

items.title: Resource Usage
items.description: BIND: High (Heavy memory footprint) | MaraDNS: Minimal (Can run on MBs of RAM)

items.title: Security History
items.description: BIND: Historically targeted, requires patching | MaraDNS: Excellent track record, designed for security

items.title: When to Use?
items.description: Use BIND for enterprise, complex topologies, or full DNSSEC. Use MaraDNS for simple, secure, low-resource embedded needs.

presentations.title: RADIUS & AAA Framework
presentations.description: A technical deep dive into AAA concepts, the RADIUS protocol, and enterprise implementations like CPAR and Radiator.

sections.title: RADIUS & AAA
sections.subtitle: Network Access Control
sections.content: Securing network boundaries with Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting.

sections.title: What is AAA?
sections.content:
**Authentication:** Who are you? (e.g., Checking username and password).

**Authorization:** What are you allowed to do? (e.g., Assigning a specific VLAN or IP address, enforcing QoS).

**Accounting:** What did you do? (e.g., Tracking session start/stop times and data transferred for billing).

items.title: Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service
items.description: An industry-standard networking protocol that provides centralized AAA management for users who connect and use a network service.

items.title: Client/Server Model
items.description: The Network Access Server (NAS) is the RADIUS Client. It passes user credentials to the RADIUS Server, which processes them against a backend database.

items.title: UDP Protocol
items.description: Historically uses UDP ports 1812 (Authentication/Authorization) and 1813 (Accounting).

items.title: Combined Action
items.description: RADIUS combines Authentication and Authorization into a single message exchange, unlike TACACS+ which separates them.

sections.title: How RADIUS Works
sections.content:
**The Authentication Flow:**

1.  **Connection Request:** Supplicant attempts to connect to the network.
2.  **Access-Request:** NAS encapsulates credentials and sends them to the RADIUS server.
3.  **Verification:** RADIUS server checks its local database or an external directory (AD/LDAP).
4.  **Access-Accept/Reject:** Server replies. If Accept, it includes authorization parameters (IP, VLAN).
5.  **Access Granted:** NAS opens the port for the user.
6.  **Accounting:** NAS sends Accounting-Request (Start) to track usage.

items.title: Access-Request
items.description: Sent by the NAS to the Server. Contains user credentials and NAS identifying information.

items.title: Access-Accept
items.description: Sent by the Server to the NAS. Authentication passed. Contains authorization attributes (AVPs) like Framed-IP-Address.

items.title: Access-Reject
items.description: Sent by the Server to the NAS. Authentication failed. The NAS denies access to the user.

items.title: Access-Challenge
items.description: Sent by the Server to the NAS. Requires further information from the user (e.g., Multi-Factor Authentication token).

items.title: Accounting-Request
items.description: Sent by the NAS to record events (Start, Stop, Interim-Update) for billing and auditing.

items.title: FreeRADIUS
items.description: The most widely used open-source RADIUS server. Extremely fast and customizable, powering many ISPs worldwide.

items.title: Cisco ISE (Identity Services Engine)
items.description: Enterprise-focused, policy-driven NAC solution. Heavyweight, GUI-driven, integrates deeply with Cisco ecosystem.

items.title: Cisco Prime Access Registrar (CPAR)
items.description: Service-provider focused AAA server. Designed for extreme scale, multi-tenancy, and complex telecom environments.

items.title: Radiator
items.description: Highly programmable, commercial AAA server known for interoperability across virtually any vendor equipment.

sections.title: Cisco Prime Access Registrar (CPAR)
sections.content: CPAR is a 3GPP-compliant, carrier-grade AAA server. Unlike enterprise ISE, CPAR is built for ISPs, Mobile Network Operators (MNOs), and massive Wi-Fi deployments. It is designed to handle thousands of transactions per second (TPS) with extremely low latency.

items.title: Carrier-Grade Performance
items.description: Optimized multi-threaded architecture capable of sustaining massive authentication loads without dropping packets.

items.title: Session Management
items.description: Maintains a real-time state database of all active sessions, crucial for enforcing concurrency limits and accurate billing.

items.title: Multi-Protocol Support
items.description: Supports RADIUS, Diameter (the successor to RADIUS used in 4G/5G), and TACACS+ natively.

items.title: Extensibility
items.description: Uses C/C++ and Java extensions to customize authentication logic, enabling integration with legacy ISP billing databases.

sections.title: Radiator AAA Server
sections.content: Radiator is a commercial AAA server known as the 'Swiss Army Knife' of RADIUS. Developed in object-oriented Perl, its primary selling point is unparalleled flexibility. If you have a strange, non-standard AAA requirement, Radiator can usually solve it.

items.title: Perl-Based Agility
items.description: Because it's written in Perl, network engineers can easily write custom Hooks (scripts) to modify packets on the fly during any stage of the authentication flow.

items.title: Extreme Interoperability
items.description: Out-of-the-box support for over 60 different EAP types and integration with almost every SQL, NoSQL, and directory database.

items.title: Complex Routing Rules
items.description: Can act as a RADIUS Proxy, making complex routing decisions based on realm names (e.g., user@domain1 goes to Server A, user@domain2 goes to Server B).

items.title: Eduroam Backbone
items.description: Radiator is the engine behind many national Eduroam proxy infrastructures due to its robust proxying capabilities.
